Comments_List:
I learned the essential concepts and facts about representations of finite groups and Lie groups. 
The proof of the fact that the dimension of any irreducible representation of a finite group divides the order of the group by arguing that the quotient of the dimension by the order is an algebraic integer is particularly illuminating.
The one-to-one correspondence between Lie algebras and simply-connected Lie groups illustrates the power of linearization in the study of Lie groups. 
It is also interesting to note that the dimension of the classical groups as manifolds can be calculated by considering their Lie algebras.

The professor teaching this course not only teaches us the material with many motivations beforehand, but also provides many valuable remarks between the various sections of this course. 
And the final presentations allow us to learn many seemingly different but deeply connected areas of representation theory, and their relations to other areas of mathematics.

This course is definitely worthwhile to take for students majoring in mathematics or physics. 
This course covers all the essential aspects of representation theory of finite groups, which demonstrates how linear algebra interacts with group theory in a very inspiring way.
Furthermore, the basics of the representation theory of Lie groups is also covered in this course, which is of interest to students of mathematics and physics alike.
